qas.question: The gyromagnetic ratio is the constant proportion between the magentic field and what?

answers.text: the frequency ν of nuclear magnetic resonance

qas.question: How does the water molecule impact the effect of magnetic fields on protons?

answers.text: The protons are said to be "shielded" from the applied magnetic field by the electrons in the water molecule

qas.question: What three factors impact the gyromagnetic ratio?

answers.text: related to the shielded proton magnetic moment μ′p, the spin number I (I = 1⁄2 for protons) and the reduced Planck constant.

qas.question: The gyromagnetic ratio is often difficult to determine due to difficulty accurately determining the value of what?
What ratio is the difference of proportionality between the frequency ν of nuclear magnetic resonance (or electron paramagnetic resonance for electrons) and the applied magnetic field?

plausible_answers.text: the shielded proton magnetic moment μ′p, the spin number I (I = 1⁄2 for protons) and the reduced Planck constant

qas.question: What three factors impact the gyroelectric ratio?
What is never related to the shielded proton magnetic moment?

plausible_answers.text: protons are said to be "shielded" from the applied magnetic field by the electrons in the water molecule

qas.question: What effect is a the same effect that gives rise to chemical shift in KMR spectroscopy?

context: The <b4_0>gyromagnetic ratio<b4_0/> γ is the constant of proportionality between <a0_0>the frequency ν of nuclear magnetic resonance<a0_0/> (or electron paramagnetic resonance for electrons) and <a3_0>the applied magnetic field B<a3_0/>: ν = γB. It is difficult to measure gyromagnetic ratios precisely because of the difficulties in precisely measuring B, but the value for protons in water at 7002298150000000000♠25 °C is known to better than one part per million. <a1_0>The <b7_0>protons are said to be "shielded" from the applied magnetic field by the electrons in the water molecule<b7_0/><a1_0/>, the same effect that gives rise to chemical shift in NMR spectroscopy, and this is indicated by a prime on the symbol for the gyromagnetic ratio, γ′p. The <b6_0>gyromagnetic ratio<b6_0/> is <a2_0>related to <b5_0>the shielded proton magnetic moment μ′p, the spin number I (I = 1⁄2 for protons) and the reduced Planck constant<b5_0/>.
